Actinomycetospora rhizophila is a species of bacterium belonging to the phylum Actinobacteria. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and filamentous actinomycete bacterium.

Some key characteristics of Actinomycetospora rhizophila:

1. Morphology: The cells are branched, and form an extensively branched substrate mycelium and an aerial mycelium.

2. Habitat: It is found in the rhizosphere (the soil surrounding plant roots) and has been isolated from the roots of various plants.

3. Physiology: Actinomycetospora rhizophila is able to degrade a variety of complex organic compounds, including cellulose and xylan. It is also able to fix atmospheric nitrogen.

4. Taxonomy: Based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis, Actinomycetospora rhizophila is closely related to other members of the genus Actinomycetospora within the family Micromonosporaceae.

5. Ecological role: As a rhizosphere-associated bacterium, Actinomycetospora rhizophila likely plays a role in plant growth promotion and nutrient cycling in the soil ecosystem.

Overall, Actinomycetospora rhizophila is a soil-dwelling, plant root-associated actinomycete with the ability to degrade complex organic matter and potentially benefit plant growth and health.
